g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
However, the degree of incidence and regional trends are quite different and a study over 14 year
indicated, on average, the largest fires in Australia, boreal North America and Northern Hemisphere
More than half of the terrestrial surface of the Earth has fire regimes outside
variability, with changes in fire frequency and intensity posing major challenges
. In some ecosystems, fire prevention might lead
to accumulation of large fuel loads that enable wildfires
About 98 Mha of forest and savannahs are estimated to have been affected by fire in 2015
forest disturbance in the tropics where about 4% of the total forest and
savannah area in that year was burned and more than two
thirds of the total area affected was in Africa
causes, with land clearing for agriculture the primary driver in tropical regions, for example, clearance
Other socioeconomic factors are also associated with wildfire
Wildfire regimes are also changing by the influence of climate change,
becoming longer, wildfire average size increases in many areas and wildfires occurring in areas where
fire weather in some regions of all inhabited continents (
fire seasons of unprecedented magnitude occurred in diverse regions as California
with unprecedented fires in British Columbia in 2021, the Arctic and Siberia
Lightning plays an important role in the ignition
of wildfires, with the incidence of lightning igniting wildfires predicted to increase with ris
esignated for production has been relatively stable since 1990. Considering forest
uses, about 30% (1.2 billion ha) of all forests is used primarily for production (wood and non
protection of soil and water, and 186 Mha is allocated for social services (recreation, tourism, education
research and the conservation of cultural and spiritual sites)
increase in the area of forest allocated primarily for biodiversity conservation has slowed in the last ten
years, the rate of increase in the area of fo
rest allocated for soil and water protection has grown since
1990, and notably in the last ten years. Global wood harvest (including from forests, other wooded land
and trees outside forests) was estimated to be almost 4.0 billion m
. Overall, wood removals are increasing globally as demand
for, and the consumption of wood products grows annually by 1% in line with growing populations and
incomes with this trend expected to continue
When done in a sustainable way, more
and is stimulated by management, resulting in a net sink. However i
logging (i.e. harvesting of timber in contravention of the laws and regulations of the
country of harvest) is a global problem with significant negative economic (e.g. lost revenue),
environmental (e.g. deforestation, forest degradation, GHG emissions and biodiversity losses) and
social impact (e.g. conflicts over land and resources, disempo
. Many countries around the world have
international trade of forest products to reduce illegal logging, with significant and positive impacts
